Locking and Unlocking a Server: stcmd server-mode

If you have appropriate access rights or privileges, you can use stcmd server-mode to lock or unlock a server configuration. Locking a server configuration limits access to it while you carry out administrative procedures. For example, you should lock the server before creating custom fields.

A nonexclusive lock (lock) permits other users to use the server, while an exclusive lock (exlock) prevents all users except the one who set the lock from using the server.

When the server configuration is unlocked, normal operations may resume.

Note: If the user name is “StarTeam,” this command requests a password for the user, even if one has already been provided or if the user has a blank password.

Syntax

stcmd server-mode [-pwdfile "filePath"] [-cmp] [-encrypt encryptionType] [-q] [-x] [-stop] -s "serverName" -mode [lock | exlock | unlock]

Example

The following example uses stcmd server-mode to nonexclusively lock the Orion server on port 49201:

stcmd server-mode -s "JMarsh:password@Orion:49201" -mode lock

 

For more information, see Using Common stcmd Options.
